Abstract
The EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulation applies to the Bayport Polymers LLC Plant (Baystar) because of the quantities of titanium tetrachloride, butene, isobutane, and ethylene safely handled in the production of high-density polyethylene (HDPE).  Long standing safety systems and programs have enabled Baystar to successfully manage the risks with no incidents impacting the community.

Background

Baystar is located at 12212 Port Road, Pasadena, TX.  TotalEnergies owned and operated the facility from 1992 until ownership transferred to Baystar on January 1st, 2018. The facility currently provides jobs for 255 fulltime Baystar employees and approximately 125 fulltime contract employees.  Baystar owns and operates two HDPE production units, Bay 1 and Bay 2. Baystar is currently constructing a Bay 3 unit which has not yet begun production.

Baystar also operates an additional production unit, called the Hydro Dearomatization (HDA) unit which is still owned by TotalEnergies. HDA is not applicable under the RMP regulations. 

Baystar has maintained an outstanding environmental and safety record through a commitment to operating the facility in a safe and responsible manner as exemplified by Baystars HSSEQ charter below: 

HEALTH SAFETY SECURITY ENVIRONMENT QUALITY CHARTER

BAYSTAR considers the safety and health of its employees and the community and protection of the environment as integral core values essential to the long-term success and sustainability of our business.

We will conduct our operations in a manner that protects the safety and health of our employees, contractors, and community as well as the quality of the environment. Our HSSEQ Charter is founded upon the values set forth in Responsible Care and its Guiding Principles and the BAYSTAR Five Core Values. No economic priority shall overrule these principles. In support of this Charter, we will:

	Design and operate our facilities to ensure operational safety, conserve resources, and minim

ize waste and emissions to demonstrate how we CARE for our employees, customers, community, and the environment. We will protect our employees, assets, information, and reputations by maintaining state-of-the art security systems. We pledge to communicate any known hazards of our operations.

	Meet or exceed all applicable laws, rules, regulations, codes, and standards in accordance with our core value of being TRUSTWORTHY. Support and encourage INNOVATIVE technologies that promote good science and engineering practices.

	Select contractors, vendors and partners who share our values and FOCUS on creating value by delivering the right solutions that are sustainable and transparent. We will only produce, market, and distribute products, that when properly used, will not pose an unacceptable risk to health and the environment while practicing effective product stewardship.

	Encourage open feedback, mutual support and sharing of best practices among our parent companies while celebrating successes and fostering an environment of FUN in our workplace. 

	Establish effective HSSEQ management systems that promote practices beyond compliance, routinely evaluate system performance and sets HSSEQ objectives at the company, department, and individual level.Seek continual improvement in HSSEQ performance with an objective to eliminate incidents and accidents.

Management and every employee and contractor have a personal responsibility to adhere to the principles set forth in this Charter. HSSEQ performance shall be an important element in all employees, contractors, and vendor evaluations. 

Applicability 

The EPA RMP regulation applies to Baystar because of the on-site quantities of titanium tetrachloride, butene, isobutane, and ethylene safely handled.  Titanium tetrachloride is on the list of EPA toxic RMP materials and is used in the manufacturing of the catalyst used in our Bay 1 process.  Butene, isobutane, and ethylene are RMP flammables.  Butene is added to the

HDPE polymer as a comonomer to control density. Isobutane is used as a solvent in the Bay 2 process.  Ethylene a feedstock in both the Bay 1 and Bay 2 processes.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

Baystars program meets or exceeds the requirements of the accidental release prevention provisions set forth in 40 CFR Part 68 by the EPA.  Our facility is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.    Baystars facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable standards and industry best practices.

The following sections briefly describe the main elements of Baystars accidental release prevention program.

1. Employee Participation - all employees at Baystar are involved in our safety program.  Baystar believes that process safety management and accident prevention are a team effort.  Company employees actively participate in accident prevention and development of our process safety management programs.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the Risk Management Plan rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.

2. Process Safety Information (PSI) - Baystar maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with our processes.  The information is kept current and is available to all employees.

3. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) - Comprehensive hazard reviews are performed on our covered processes to ensure that hazards are identified, evaluated, and controlled effectively.  The reviews are performed by a multi-disciplinary team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations.  Entire PHAs are revalidated every 5-year and updated as required for changes to the process.  Any findings from the hazard analysis are addressed promptly. 

4. Operating Pr

ocedures - In order to safely operate our facility, Baystar maintains detailed written operating procedures.  These procedures cover initial plant startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround.  They define tasks which must perform, safe operating parameters that must be maintain, and safety precautions for operations and maintenance activities. The procedures are reviewed regularly and are readily accessible to our Operators.

5. Training - Baystar has a formal training program to ensure that all employees who operate the processes are trained and tested in the operating procedures and activities associated with these processes. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.  During the training, each employee must demonstrate that they have the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities as provided in our operating procedures.

6. Contractors - Our company hires contractors to perform maintenance and construction activities at the facility.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is performed.  Baystar has a strict work permitting program for informing the contractors of known hazards related to the contractor's work and our processes.  Contractors are also informed of the emergency response procedures should an accidental release occur.

7. Pre-Startup Safety Review - Pre-start up safety reviews are conducted on new facilities and modifications of established facilities at Baystar.  These reviews confirm that construction and equipment are suitable for safe startup, operating and maintenance procedures are in place and adequate, and that hazards have been evaluated before placing equipment into operation.

8. Mechanical Integrity  Baystar has a comprehensive preventive maintenance and mechanical integrity program in place

for the entire facility.  The program incorporates industry codes, federal and state regulations, and recommendations from equipment manufacturers.  Baystar carries out documented maintenance inspections and tests on process equipment and controls to ensure proper operation. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

9. Management of Change  A written Management of change procedure is used at Baystar to authorize and manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  All changes are evaluated to determine potential impacts to our current operating procedures, operating parameters, and safety control systems.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, and other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and provided training on any modification.

10. Incident Investigation - Baystar promptly investigates any incident or near miss that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release or injury.  These investigations identify the root-causes leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions necessary to prevent a release or injury from reoccurring.  Investigation report findings are shared with all employees affected by the findings.

Five-Year Accident History

Baystar has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases.  Due to our stringent safety program, there have been no releases of any RMP regulated chemicals meeting the 5-year accident history criteria for impact on the community, environment, or plant personnel at our facility.

Emergency Response Program

Baystar has a written emergency response plan to manage potential accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan contains procedures for first aid and medical treatment, site evacuation, notification/com

munication to regulatory agencies and the public, on and offsite air monitoring, and post-incident clean-up of any affected areas.  The emergency response plan is reviewed and updated to incorporate any pertinent changes to our processes. Baystar is an active members of the Southeast Regional LEPC, our facility's Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), participating in meetings and emergency drills. Participation in the LEPC ensure our emergency plan is coordinated with local municipalities including Harris County Office or Emergency Management. Baystar is also an active member of the Seabrook Citizens Advisory Panel (SeaCAP) 

Baystar employs trained emergency responders, including industrial firefighters trained at the Texas A&M University Industrial Fire Fighting School.  Baystar also has an onsite emergency medical team and an onsite rescue team.  Our hazardous materials response team is HAZMAT certified and can respond to incidents both on and offsite.  Additional contract personnel can also provide emergency response equipment, expertise, and manpower if needed to clean up larger spills.

To quickly and effectively respond to emergencies, Baystar maintains both a mobile aerial foam truck and a fast attack truck onsite.  The entire plant is surrounded by an underground firewater header to supply firewater from our 1.2-million-gallon firewater storage tank.  In addition, our firewater system is also tied into the fire water system of the neighboring plant. This serves both as a backup to our system and offers additional firewater capacity if needed.  Fixed fire monitors and deluge systems are strategically placed throughout the facility to respond to fires.  Baystar operates 2 flares to safely combust flammable chemicals during shutdowns, upsets, or emergencies.  To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.

Baystar operates a site emergency alarm system to alert on-site personnel and neighbors to emergen

cies.  Our emergency radio system links offsite responders at neighboring facilities to our communication system.  Baystar also notifies regulators and the community of active incidents through the Harris Countys Office of emergency Managements Emerge system and the CAER line.  Baystar closely coordinate our emergency plan with Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) and can quickly request additional assistance by radio or telephone.  CIMA is the largest industry mutual aid organization in the world.  It is a joining together of firefighting, rescue, hazardous materials, and emergency medical manpower and equipment from more than 100 industrial facilities and federal, state, and local emergency response agencies in the Houston area for mutual assistance in case of an emergency.  Our responders participate in the annual CIMA Zone 4 Drill and the annual general membership drill.

Continual Improvement

Continual improvement is an integral component of our risk management program.  Baystar recognizes that even the best system can be improved.  Several capital improvements have been made to further improve safety at our facility in the last 5-years.  These include implementation of alarm management, installation of additional control instrumentation and safety interlocks, removal of a CFC system, upgrades to existing PSVs (pressure safety valves) and installation of additional PSVs and reliability improvements to rotating equipment seals.
